journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Effects of flow inertia modelling and valve-plate geometry on swash-plate axial-piston pump performance

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Jadavpur University, Kolkata, India

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, Jadavpur University, Raja SC Mullick Road, Kolkata, West Bengal 700032, India. email: rsaha@mech.jdvu.ac.in

abstract.p: The present work aims at developing a methodology for designing a swash-plate axial-piston pump whose barrel kidneys are wider than the bridges separating the kidney ports on the plate. Besides reducing pressure ripples and avoiding cavitation for minimizing the fluid-borne noise, maximization of the pump discharge has also been considered in formulating an objective function to be minimized. A comprehensive mathematical model considering oil compressibility and inertia has been developed and implemented in MATLAB/Simulink for dynamic simulation of the pump flow. The model has been found acceptable by observing a good match between its predictions of mean discharge and delivery pressure and available experimental results. A detailed parametric study has been performed and the optimum angles for the valve-plate pre-compression and the barrel kidneys have been obtained.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Swash-plate axial-piston pumps are used as the power source in many hydraulic systems. Hibi et al. [1, 2] examined the suction performance of a stationary valve-plate design. Such a valve plate, as shown in Fig. 1, has kidney-shaped suction and delivery ports separated by two bridges, all located about a common pitch circle. On the same pitch circle, there are a number of bores in a barrel that rotates over the valve plate. Each barrel bore, which is essentially cylindrical, is given a matching kidney shape of smaller angular extent towards the valve plate. Along the cylindrical part of each bore, a piston reciprocates due to its rotation over a stationary inclined swash plate with which the piston head is joined by the piston shoe. The reciprocation makes the oil volume inside the bore alternately expand and contract. Of course, the expansion causes de-compression of oil when a bore passes over a bridge from the delivery port to the suction port followed by suction of oil from a reservoir as long as the bore rotates over the suction port. Subsequently, the contraction causes compression of the oil when the bore crosses the opposite bridge and discharge to the hydraulic circuit when the bore moves over the delivery port. Smaller pitch of the circle and larger barrel of the bores were found to be better for the avoidance of cavitation.

caption.p: Schematic illustration of the swash-plate axial-piston pump

sec.p: Manring [3] analysed the flow ripples in an axial-piston pump that are due to acceleration and deceleration of the pistons relative to the barrel. Ivantysyn and Ivantysynova [4] made a detailed model of the leakages between the valve plate and the barrel, each piston and its barrel bore, and through a capillary along the axis of each piston. These not only minimize the structure-borne noise due to the lubricating effect, but also reduce the chance of flow ripples developing into pressure ripples during the compression and decompression. Ortwig [5] mentioned the pressure ripples as the principal source of fluid-borne noise. The pressure ripples become very prominent if the barrel-kidney angle is less than the bridge angle, since this provides a trapped volume of oil within a barrel bore over a bridge when the bore gets disconnected from both ports. However, Manring [6] found such design to provide higher volumetric efficiency.

Different methods have been employed in the past for minimizing the fluid-borne noise. Manring [7] analysed the effect of geometry of the silencing groove, also referred to as the relief groove, since it acts as variable-area orifice through which the leakage minimizes the pressure ripples. Pettersson et al. [8] considered connecting a pre-compression filter volume, or PCFV, with the trapped volume for reducing the ripples. Harrison and Edge [9] arrived at a successful design in which the port approached by the rotating bore acts also as the PCFV by pro-viding an auxiliary flow path between it and the trapped volume through a check valve. Recently, Wang [10] has analysed an overlapped valve-plate design, also referred to as the cross-port design. This design is characterized by bridge angle smaller than the barrel-kidney angle. In this design, the barrel bore provides a direct leakage path between the ports in the valve plate prior to the disconnection of the bore with the port in the trail. Since this design can be viewed as utilizing both the ports as PCFV, the management of pressure ripples and cavitation is expected to be less sensitive to the variation of the design parameters.

It has been found that any valve-plate design minimizes the fluid-borne noise at a definite pre-compression angle, also called the index angle. At zero angle, the midpoint of the portion of the pitch circle on a bridge falls on the axis of the piston, when it ceases to reciprocate momentarily. For positive angles, setting up of the connection between the barrel kidney and the discharge groove gets delayed. Li [11] conducted an experimental study on a pump with a valve plate having cross-porting and pre-compression angle. Johansson et al. [12] designed a Pareto-optimal cross-angled swash plate, where the cross angle is a small fixed angle in the direction perpendicular to the inclination that governs the piston displacement. Of course, the cross angle induces an intrinsic change in the valve-plate pre-compression angle by 90° with change in displacement angle of the swash plate from the rated full discharge to no discharge. In the whole range of displacement angle variation, the cross-angle design was experimentally established to be better than that without the cross angle. Ensuring a cavitation-free operation was not explicit in their chosen optimality criterion.

In this perspective, a cavitation-free optimal design of an axial-piston pump with cross-port valve plate has been taken up in the present paper by updating the modelling due to Mandal et al. [13]. A swash plate without any cross angle has been considered and, following Manring [7], its displacement angle has been referred to as the swash angle. This angle, together with the pre-compression angle, has been designed for minimizing the delivery pressure ripple and maximizing the discharge. The models of Manring [6, 7] and Edge and Darling [14] consider each groove as an extension of the connected port. However, following Mandal et al. [13], a silencing groove has been modelled as a volume separate from its adjoining port. The effect of oil inertia ignored by Mandal et al. [13] has been incorporated in a method that is similar to the modelling of Edge and Darling [14]. Also, both compressibility and density of oil have been taken as variable. This contrasts with the work of Ma et al. [15], who modelled oil to have variable compressibility but constant density. In order to focus attention on the analysis of the pump, it has been assumed that a simple needle valve between the pump delivery and the reservoir provides the hydraulic loading of the pump.

sec.title: 2 Mathematical Model
sec.p: With reference to Fig. 1, the maximum stroke and the instantaneous position of a piston are expressed in terms barrel pitch radius Rp, swash angle λ, and speed of barrel rotation ω as
and

where δ is the pre-compression angle, β is the bridge angle, and i denotes any piston or barrel bore identified by numbers between 1 and the total number of pistons n, taken equal to 9 in this study. Figure 1 depicts the instantaneous positions of all of the bores by putting the respective numbers at the barrel kidneys. Figure 1 also details the stroking of the first piston by developing section XX and showing the piston position at times t = 0 and
t = − ( β / 2 + δ ) / ω
. The inset in Fig. 1 indicates that the two grooves considered here are bounded by two triangles at the inlet and exit.

The discharges have been considered as positive for each bore in the direction from top dead centre (TDC) to bottom dead centre (BDC), for groove 1 towards the delivery port, and for groove 2 towards the bore. Thus, the discharges at the inlets of grooves 1 and 2 are Q1vi and Q2c, respectively, and those at the exits are Q1c and Q2vi, respectively, where c and v stand respectively for the constant and time-varying flow areas. These constant and varying areas pertain respectively to the triangular flow interface between the port and its associated groove and that between the groove and part of the kidney-shaped ith bore exposed to the groove at an instant. In Fig. 1, these areas corresponding to groove 2 have been indicated respectively by triangle bcd and part of triangle abc overlapped by the sixth barrel kidney. In terms of the flow variables described in Table 1, various discharges through different orifice passages in the pump can be expressed as

caption.p: Description of orifice flow variables at different locations

sec.p: Estimation of the opening areas described in Table 1 has been detailed by Mandal et al. [13] in terms of different geometric parameters like thebarrel-kidney angle γ.

An important feature of the present modelling is incorporating the inertia effect of the oil along with its compressibility in all of the bores and the grooves, each considered as separate volume elements. Figure 1 shows the local coordinate directions xp1, xg1, and xg2 for piston 1, groove 1, and groove 2, respectively. In particular, the inlet and exit locations of each groove are described by the coordinate values of zero and lg, which can be expressed by using Fig. 2 as

The total flow coming out from all of the pistons and grooves to the delivery port is denoted as the pump delivery flow QD written as
Similarly, pump suction flow QS is denoted by the total flow entering into all of the pistons and grooves written as
Equations (1) to (5c) and (8a) to (13) need to be solved simultaneously for predicting the flow dynamics of the system under study.

sec.title: 3 Solution Methodology And Validation
sec.p: The equations developed in section 2 are a set of first-order differential equations for pressure dynamics along with a set of algebraic equations for the discharges. Simultaneous solution of these equations provides the pressure and flow characteristics of individual pistons as well as the overall pump. The equations are solved using MATLAB/Simulink version 7.01. Parameters other than pressure and flow are calculated using ‘S-function’ in the MATLAB environment. The input to the ‘S-function’ is the instantaneous angular displacement θ, which has been obtained by integrating ω with respect to time. Design parameters such as different physical dimensions and swash angle are defined internally as the other inputs. The outputs of the ‘S-function’ are the different areas, groove volumes, and coefficients for leakage flows that are fed to the respective Simulink blocks.

For starting the simulation, the flow and pressure conditions need to be initialized. The initialization has been done by simultaneously solving all of the equations mentioned after dropping the transient terms of the dynamic equations. A Runge–Kutta fourth-order solver with a fixed time step equal to 2 × 10–9 s has been employed. The variation of oil compressibility employed in obtaining the results has been taken to be that given by Ma et al. [15]. Table 2 lists the oil properties and component sizes used in the theoretical simulation. These values have been used to validate the model by comparing its prediction against the experimental results provided by Li [11].

caption.p: Parameter values used in obtaining the predictions of Fig. 3
Effect of choice of integration time step on numerical prediction of pump discharge

sec.p: Besides the values available in the thesis of Li [11], a number of values that have been adopted in the simulation have been marked in Table 2 by bold numbers. A good matching of the mean values of the pulsating discharge and delivery pressure is evident. Of course, the ripples present in the experimental data are quite higher than the prediction. However, in comparison to the ripples in the predictions of Johansson et al. [12] with respect to their experimental data, the predicted ripples in Fig. 3 are distinctly higher. The difference between the prediction and the experimental readings may be due to the pipeline turbulence.

Effects of flow inertia modelling and cross-port valve-plate geometry for a swash plate without any cross angle have been studied for reducing fluid-borne noise in the pump by a fixed setting of the pre-compression angle. It may be mentioned here that instead of using the pre-compression angle, Ma et al. [15] described the position of the valve plate relative to the barrel by what they called the cross angle. However, Johansson et al. [12] used the term cross angle in the context of the swash plate.

sec.title: 4 Results and Discussion
sec.p: In Figs 4 to 7, variations of different pressures and discharges have been presented versus barrel dis-placement. In the part of the subscript before the comma, an ‘s’ or ‘d’ indicates the volume element as suction or delivery port respectively, ‘p1’ stands for piston 1, and ‘g1’ or ‘g2’ for groove 1 or 2, respectively. In Fig. 4, a ‘w’ and ‘wo’ in the subscript after the comma respectively indicate the predictions to be the outcome of modelling with and without the oil inertia effect. In the former model, each groove is taken as a separate volume element and in the latter model it has been integrated with the port. The latter model is obtained from the inertial model by neglecting the flow transient terms and the variation of the area of the grooves from the inlet to exit with respect to (Vg/lg), along with taking the bulk modulus of oil to be much higher than the dynamic pressure within a volume element. Under these cir-cumstances, equations (7) to (9) simplify to the forms as obtained earlier by Mandal et al. [13]. In Figs 5 to 7, the number after the comma in the subscript represents the valve pre-compression angle in degrees. In Fig. 8, by analysing the sensitivity of reducing pressure ripple and the chance of cavitation with changes in design parameters and operating conditions, an optimal design procedure has been established.

caption.p: Effect of oil inertia on predicted pressure and flow ripples
Discharges between piston 1 and ports for valve-plate pre-compression angle of 12° (a) and 19° (b)
Piston chamber pressure for valve-plate pre-compression angles of 12° and 19° for piston motion near BDC (a) and TDC (b)
Identification of cross-port discharge for valve-plate pre-compression angles of 12° and 19° for piston motion near BDC (a) and TDC (b)
Effects of variations in design parameters and system variables on delivery pressure ripple (a, b), cavitation (c, d), and discharge (e, f)

sec.title: 4.1 Effects of flow inertia modelling
sec.p: Figures 4(a) and (b) provide the comparison of flow variables predicted by models incorporating and neglecting inertia effects. Figure 4(a) exhibits the inertia effect as significant only as long as a barrel moves over the delivery port. When the inertia effect is considered, the predicted pressure within a pump barrel during this part of the motion is observed to be more in comparison to that obtained by ignoring the effect. This implies that the prediction of the model without the inertia effect would have exhibited inferior matching of the mean pressure with respect to experimental variation shown in Fig. 3. In the scale used in Fig. 4(b) for the pressures, the difference in the predictions by the two models over the delivery port is more apparent. Figures 4(c) and (d) show the predictions of the inertia model for the discharges involving groove 1, or the delivery groove, which is near the TDC and the difference of the pressure of this groove with respect to that in the delivery port. Predictions of both the models have a periodicity of 40° that is indeed due to nine pistons considered in the study.

Within each 40°, two oscillations can be noticed in the without-inertia prediction of Fig. 4(b). The first and third peaks are identical on account of the periodicity. However, the intermediate peak is relatively weaker. On the other hand, the inertia model-predicted intensity of the peaks at the corresponding locations exhibits the opposite nature. In between the first peak that is relatively weaker and the peak that is strongest, a mild hump is evident in the latter prediction. This is due to the fact that the rate of discharge terms present in this model imparts higher-order behaviour to the ripples. The amplitude of the observed oscillations of this model in Fig. 4(b) is understandably lower, since the inertia model attributes the oil mass the capacity to accumulate and discharge energy during the transient phase. Although Edge and Darling [14] have demonstrated the inertial model to be of higher order, their study ignored the pulsating nature of pressure in the delivery port.

The first peak in Fig. 4(b) is attained when the leading edge of the second barrel kidney touches the apex of groove 1. For a brief interval afterwards, piston 2, in spite of being on the delivery groove, executes the terminating phase of the suction stroke from BDC to TDC, whereas piston 3 (remaining partly over the delivery groove) continues its delivery stroke and piston 1 (staying fully over the suction port) carries on with the suction stroke. These are evident from Fig. 4(c) by negative Q1v2, positive Q1v3, and zero Q1v1 pertaining to barrels 2, 3, and 1 respectively. The subsequent fall in the groove pressure can be attributed to the mass depletion inside the control volume associated with the net negative discharge
(

from the groove. This negative discharge is apparent in Fig. 4(c) which arises due to the domination of the outgoing discharges to barrel 2 and the delivery port over the incoming discharge from barrel 3. One curve in Fig. 4(d) corresponds to the variations of the outgoing discharge Q1c, shown in Fig. 1 to be through the exit of groove 1 to the delivery port. The other curve pertains to the pressure difference

between groove 1 and the delivery port. Since this exit is an orifice of constant area Ac, the predicted variations are consistent with equation (3).

Figure 4(c) captures the end of the suction stroke of piston 2 as the point after which the discharge Q2v1 from barrel 2 to groove 1 becomes positive. As piston 2 approaches the TDC, piston 3 starts gradually leaving the silencing groove which gives rise to decreasing discharge Q1v3 from its barrel to the groove. A short phase of slowing down of the net depletion of the oil mass characterized by an almost constant negative value of
(

is evident in Fig. 4(c). The inertia model-predicted humps in Fig. 4(b) are related to these slow depletion phases. Figure 4(c) exhibits a subsequent phase of pressure rise within groove 1 that corresponds to the period revealed in Fig. 4(b) beginning with the delivery stroke of piston 2 up until the discharge Q1v2 from the second barrel to the groove reaches the maximum. The subsequent fall and rise of pressures in both the delivery port and the groove seen in Fig. 4(b) up until the next peak follow the nature of variation of the pump discharge shown in Fig. 3. Due to rotation of the piston group, periodic variations take place in the velocity of each piston, the number of barrel kidneys over the delivery port, and their extent of overlap. Of course, the pulsating nature of the discharge is consistent with the complex nature of flow interaction between multiple barrels and the port.

During the phase of single-piston interaction with groove 1, no net accumulation is evidenced by Fig. 4(c). It conforms indeed to the increase and decrease of the discharge through the variable area at the groove inlet also depicted in Fig. 4(c), having identical trend with the discharge through the constant area at the groove exit apparent in Fig. 4(d). The predicted variation of the discharge in Fig. 3 can be seen to be consistent with the pressure ripples in Fig. 4(b) corresponding to the inertia model.

sec.title: 4.2 Effects of valve-plate pre-compression angle and cross-port design
sec.p: Figure 5 depicts the variation of discharges between the ports and piston 1 with respect to the barrel displacement from the reference line shown in Fig. 1. Angles of the barrel kidney and each bridge respectively equal to 30° and 26° have been considered, for which the cross-port angle is 4°. The discharges have been predicted by equation (3) corresponding to the suction and delivery ports. During most of the rotation, the discharges take place from the suction port to a bore and from a bore to the delivery port indicated by positive values in Figs 5(a) and (b). However, near the TDC and BDC, Figs 5(a) and (b) indicate small phases of reverse flow, marked as A and B put inside circles. Allowing these flow reversals by proper valve-plate design can be envisaged as a ploy of containing the up and down spikes in the chamber pressure shown in Fig. 6. Figure 5 shows that for the larger pre-compression angle, the maximum reverse discharges near both TDC and BDC are lower. Figure 7 depicts the discharges about the TDC and BDC in greater detail for 12° and 19° pre-compression angle of the valve plate.

Figure 6 depicts the pressure build-up characteristics inside the piston chamber. It shows that for the larger pre-compression angle the pressure peaks near the BDC and the TDC are lower than the ones for the smaller pre-compression angle. In fact, the variation of pressure within a barrel bore shown in Fig. 6(b) is quite similar to what has been found out by Wang [10]. Figure 7 highlights the variations of discharges between each port and a barrel bore in the vicinity of velocity reversal of the piston near its TDC and BDC shown in Fig. 1. During these phases, indeed a barrel bore rotates over a bridge being connected simultaneously to both the delivery and suction ports. The bore is leaving a port in the trail and is establishing increasing overlap with the groove of the other port. Therefore, flow could simultaneously take place between a barrel bore and both the ports at two extreme angular extents of the bridge. If groove 2 gets connected to a bore prior to completion of the downward piston stroke near the BDC, a discharge from both the bore and the delivery port to the suction groove could take place due to the influence of suction port pressure. Figure 7 shows these discharges respectively as positive and negative, which are consistent with the sign convention used in writing equation (3).

It is possible to have a reverse discharge from the delivery port to the piston chamber approaching the BDC by the rise of the port pressure due to the entry of a piston chamber over it after crossing the TDC. There could also be a reverse discharge to the suction port from a piston chamber approaching the TDC by the drop of the port pressure due to entering of a piston chamber over the port after crossing the BDC. In case of 19° pre-compression angle, the portions of the curve marked as hij in Fig. 7(a) and as h1i1j1 in Fig. 7(b) represent these reverse discharges. Indeed Fig. 6(a) exhibits pressure in the chamber of piston 1 to be lower than the delivery port pressure corresponding to the displacement range of hij in Fig. 7(a). For the pre-compression angle of 12°, no reverse discharges are evident in Figs 7(a) and (b). Moreover, as revealed by Fig. 6(a), the piston chamber pressure for this angle remains considerably above the port pressure up to the point of its getting disconnected from the delivery port.

Reverse discharges are also apparent in Fig. 7 in the zones marked as aefg and a1e1f1g1 for 19° pre-compression angle and in the zones marked as abcd and a1b1c1d1 for 12° angle. Starting from about a, up to point f or c the reverse flow to the suction port takes place through groove 2, and starting from about a1, up to point f1 or c1 the reverse flow from the delivery port takes place through groove 1. Of course, higher reverse discharge arises due to higher piston speed towards the corresponding groove yielding a stronger pressure ripple manifested as higher rate of change in piston chamber pressure in Fig. 6. Clearly, both the compression and decompression pressure ripples are much lower in intensity for 19° pre-compression angle.

The effect of another important aspect of the cross-port design has been analysed in Figs 8 and 9. Besides the variations of time-averaged discharge through the needle valve, the other performance parameters that have been studied are the delivery-port pressure ripple coefficient and the cavitation number corresponding to the minimum pressure within a barrel bore. By dividing with the time-averaged delivery pressure
P
¯
d
the difference between the maximum compression pressure Pp,max within a barrel bore and the minimum pressure Pd,min at the delivery port, the ripple coefficient has been expressed as

caption.p: Effects of design and system variables on cavitation-free operation

sec.p: On the other hand, the cavitation number [16] has been defined corresponding to the minimum decompression pressure Pp,min within a barrel bore as

where Pa is the ambient pressure relative to which the suction and delivery pressures have been estimated, Pv is the vapour pressure of the oil at a reference temperature, and Pls is the prescribed reserve to compensate the loss of pressure expected in the suction line and the strainer at the pump inlet. Galal Rabie [17] recommended 0.3 bar to 0.4 bar for the cavitation reserve. The vapour pressure of oil has been taken as 1.0 Pa [18].

Figures 8(a), (c), and (e) show the variations of the ripple coefficient, the cavitation number, and the needle-valve discharge with the pre-compression angle for different barrel-kidney angles. Of course, these angles constitute the design parameters. The effects of different operating variables, namely the motor r/min, the swash angle λ of the pump, and the delivery pressure Pd, on the variations of the performance parameters with the pre-compression angle have been presented in Figs 8(b), (d), and (f) for a fixed barrel-kidney angle of 30°. In all the subsequent analysis, the cavitation reserve has been taken as 0.4 bar.

Figures 8(a) and (b) show that the ripple coefficient remains close to and below 0.06 in the ranges from 21° to 27° pre-compression angle, 28° to 32° barrel-kidney angle, 10° to 20° swash angle, 1800r/min to 3600 r/min motor speed, and 6.6 MPa to 26.5 MPa maximum delivery pressure obtained by setting the orifice opening area appropriately. Within these ranges, Figs 8(c) and (d) reveal the maximum of the cavitation number to lie in a much narrower zone, and Figs 8(e) and (f) exhibit maximization of discharge for a definite design and operating point. The expected trend of higher needle-valve discharges at larger swash angle and higher rot-ational speed are consistent with the adopted means of increasing the pump discharge irrespective of the circuit loading, respectively in variable-displacement and variable-speed pump designs. At higher pump discharge, the pressure drop at fixed orifice diameter of the needle valve is definitely higher. Higher delivery pressure leads to lower prediction of the ripple coefficient over the ranges mentioned regarding Figs 8(a) and (b). Of course, positive cavitation number corresponds to no cavitation. Dividing a positive cavitation number by the maximum cavitation number σn,max, the cavitation-free zone has been shown in Figs 9(a) and (b).

sec.title: 4.3 Optimization of valve-plate pre-compression angle and barrel-kidney angle
sec.p: A two-parameter objective function to be maximi-zed has been defined as

are the flow, ripple, and cavitation factors, respectively. The first two factors have been normalized to respective maximum and minimum of 1 and 0 by the denominators Qd,max and σr,max, which are respectively the maximum discharge and ripple coefficient in the entire design space investigated. In cases where the cavi-tation number is positive, the third factor becomes zero, and if it is negative, an infinite-barrier penalty [19] of – 2 × 105 is attributed. Thus, the maximization by equation (15) searches for the optimum combination of the barrel-kidney and pre-compression angles only in the cavitation-free zone. Obviously equation (15) indicates that the objective function could attain the maximum of 2, if the maximum flow condition is achieved at a design point without any delivery pressure ripple. Table 3 presents the variation of the objective function. The maximum of 1.99 indicates that for 30° barrel-kidney angle and 21° pre-compression angle, the optimal design yields the maximum discharge with minimal delivery ripple almost concurrently.

caption.p: Variation of objective function with design parameters

sec.p: A large parameter range is apparent in Table 3 where cavitation-free operation is not possible. Towards the beginning and end of the suction stroke of a piston, the oil flow from the suction port to the barrel kidney takes place through an orifice-like opening, when a large portion of the barrel kidney remains over a bridge and a much smaller portion over the port. These present two possible situations, when cavitation may take place due to insufficient oil flow to the bore in comparison to the volume expansion related to the piston stroking. Towards the end of the stroke, this could be due to reducing orifice area. The large negative pressure within the barrel bore in Fig. 6(b) corresponding to 30° barrel-kidney angle and 12° pre-compression angle is clear evidence of such cavitation. Beyond a particular pre-compression angle, such cavitation does not happen due to setting up of increasingly larger orifice area at the end of the suction stroke. Of course, the lower the cross-porting angle, the higher is the required value of the pre-compression angle.

A large pre-compression angle makes the piston velocity too high, when a barrel kidney just leaves the delivery manifold. During this pre-compression period, oil flow to the barrel kidney takes place only from the suction port through an increasing orifice area. Also, the expanding volume within the barrel bore at that instant is quite small. The cavitation could take place due to the combination of the high piston velocity and small bore volume. This explains another bound of the pre-compression angle, beyond which the cavitation within a bore following its entry over the suction port could take place. It is understandable that Table 3 reveals a smaller difference between the bounds for smaller cross-port angle. A cross-port angle less than 3° makes the cavitation inevitable irrespective of the pre-compression angle, unless other sizes are not changed.

Table 3 shows the design combination of 30° barrel-kidney angle and 21° pre-compression angle to be Pareto-optimal, since any change away from this combination does not reveal any increase in the listed value of the objective function. The objective functions have been given in Table 4 corresponding to different delivery pressures achieved due to changes listed in Table 5. The values in Table 4 show the change in any positive objective function with the variations in the system variables to be within 95 per cent of the maximum value. For the combination of 3600 r/min rotational speed and 20° swash angle, Table 5 indicates the delivery pressure to be equal to 26.5 MPa for which Table 4 reveals cavitation-free operation to be not achievable even by changing the pre-compression angle.

caption.p: Variation of objective function with system variables at design point
Variation of objective function with system variables at design point

sec.title: 5 Conclusions
sec.p: A detailed modelling of the flow dynamics for a swash-plate axial-piston pump has been achieved. It has been found that the oil inertia has significant influence on the predicted flow variables. The optimum combination of the valve-plate pre-compression angle and the barrel-kidney angle in a cross-port valve-plate design has been determined at a particular operating pressure of 7.0 MPa. Besides the maximization of the discharge and the minimization of the pressure ripple, the avoidance of cavitation has also been ensured in the optimization by setting a two-parameter objective function. It has been found that these angles yield near-optimal performance at higher pressures as well.

sec.p: Ac constant area of each groove (m2)
